title: tidymodels workshop
text: This workshop provides an introduction to machine learning with R using the tidymodels framework, a collection of packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles. We will build, evaluate, compare, and tune predictive models. Along the way, we‚Äôll learn about key concepts in machine learning including overfitting, resampling, and feature engineering. Learners will gain knowledge about good predictive modeling practices, as well as hands-on experience using tidymodels packages like parsnip, rsample, recipes, yardstick, tune, and workflows.

title: tidymodels workshop
text:
Installation
Please join the workshop with a computer that has the following installed (all available for free):

A recent version of R, available at https://cran.r-project.org/
A recent version of RStudio Desktop (RStudio Desktop Open Source License, at least v2022.02), available at https://www.rstudio.com/download
The following R packages, which you can install from the R console:


install.packages(c("tidyverse", "tidymodels", "modeldata", "kknn",  
                   "ranger",  "rpart", "rpart.plot", 
                   "partykit", "vetiver", "xgboost"))

title: tidymodels workshop
text:

1: Introduction
2: A minimal model
3: A better workflow
4: A tuned workflow

title: Introduction to tidymodels
text: whoami

title: Introduction to tidymodels
text:
Our goals for this workshop

Introduce tidymodels and its general philosophy on modeling.
Help you become proficient with the core packages for modeling.
Point you to places to learn more and get help.

title: Introduction to tidymodels
text:
Why tidymodels?
There are several other modeling frameworks in R that try to:

create a uniform, cohesive, and unsurprising set of modeling APIs

Examples are caret, mlr3, and others.

caret is more favorable for people who prefer base R/traditional interfaces.
mlr3 is more pythonic and also has many features.
tidymodels would probably be preferable to those who place importance on a tidy R interface, a large number of features, and the idea that the interfaces should enable the ‚Äúpit of success‚Äù.

title: Introduction to tidymodels
text:
The tidymodels package
There are a lot of tidymodels packages but about 90% of the work is done by 5 packages. (rsample, recipes, parsnip, tune, and yardstick)
The best way to get started with tidymodels is to use the tidymodels meta-package. It loads the core packages plus some tidyverse packages.
Some helpful links:

List of all tidymodels functions
List of all parsnip models
List of all recipe steps


click on the search button on tidymodels.org for all those lists

title: Introduction to tidymodels
text:
The tidymodels package

library(tidymodels)
#> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidymodels 0.2.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ
#> ‚úî broom        0.8.0          ‚úî rsample      0.1.1     
#> ‚úî dials        1.0.0.9000     ‚úî tibble       3.1.7     
#> ‚úî dplyr        1.0.9          ‚úî tidyr        1.2.0     
#> ‚úî infer        1.0.0          ‚úî tune         0.2.0.9002
#> ‚úî modeldata    0.1.1          ‚úî workflows    0.2.6.9001
#> ‚úî parsnip      1.0.0.9000     ‚úî workflowsets 0.2.1     
#> ‚úî purrr        0.3.4          ‚úî yardstick    1.0.0.9000
#> ‚úî recipes      0.2.0.9001
#> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidymodels_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
#> ‚úñ purrr::discard() masks scales::discard()
#> ‚úñ dplyr::filter()  masks stats::filter()
#> ‚úñ dplyr::lag()     masks stats::lag()
#> ‚úñ recipes::step()  masks stats::step()
#> ‚Ä¢ Learn how to get started at https://www.tidymodels.org/start/

title: Introduction to tidymodels
text:
Managing name conflicts

tidymodels_prefer(quiet = FALSE)
#> [conflicted] Will prefer dplyr::filter over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer dplyr::select over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer dplyr::slice over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer dplyr::rename over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer dials::neighbors over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer parsnip::fit over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer parsnip::bart over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer parsnip::pls over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer purrr::map over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer recipes::step over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer themis::step_downsample over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer themis::step_upsample over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer tune::tune over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer yardstick::precision over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer yardstick::recall over any other package
#> [conflicted] Will prefer yardstick::spec over any other package
#> ‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidymodels_prefer() ‚îÄ‚îÄ

title: Building models
text:
hello world

goal: predict well on unseen data!
data budget:

initial split: graph and code
only use test set once!

models via parsnip

model (glm): spec, fit, predict, measure. notice difference in performance between train and test?
2nd model (them. decision tree?): spec, fit - but if we were to measure on test set again, it would not be unseen. we‚Äôre then optimizing for performance on that one test set!

resampling

some graphs to illustrate, the analysis/assessment one for sure
I do glm: vfold_cv(), fit_resamples()
they do their model
let‚Äôs compare

title: Building models
text:
Data splitting and spending
For machine learning, we typically split data into training and test sets:


The training set is used to estimate model parameters.
The test set is used to find an independent assessment of model performance.



Do not üö´ use the test set during training.

title: Building models
text:
Data splitting and spending

Spending too much data in training prevents us from computing a good assessment of predictive performance.
Spending too much data in testing prevents us from computing a good estimate of model parameters.

title: Building models
text:
Data splitting and spending 

set.seed(123)
alz_split <- initial_split(alz, strata = Class, prop = .9)
alz_split
#> <Analysis/Assess/Total>
#> <298/35/333>



other split function: initial_time_split()
point out sizes

title: Building models
text:
Data splitting and spending 

alz_train <- training(alz_split) 
alz_test <- testing(alz_split)

c(nrow(alz_train), nrow(alz_test))
#> [1] 298  35

lm for linear model

title: Building models
text:
To specify a model 



Choose a model
Specify an engine
Set the mode



logistic_reg() %>% 
  set_engine("glm") %>% 
  set_mode("classification")
#> Logistic Regression Model Specification (classification)
#> 
#> Computational engine: glm

All available models are listed at https://www.tidymodels.org/find/parsnip/


many models

in parsnip and extension packages

title: Building models
text:
To fit a model
Now we‚Äôve specified a model

lr_spec <- logistic_reg() %>% 
  set_engine("glm") %>% 
  set_mode("classification")


How do we use it?


We can fit it to our data

lr_fit <- lr_spec %>% 
  fit(Class ~ tau + VEGF, 
      data = alz)

lr_fit
#> parsnip model object
#> 
#> 
#> Call:  stats::glm(formula = Class ~ tau + VEGF, family = stats::binomial, 
#>     data = data)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#> (Intercept)          tau         VEGF  
#>      8.9747      -4.0095       0.9337  
#> 
#> Degrees of Freedom: 332 Total (i.e. Null);  330 Residual
#> Null Deviance:       390.6 
#> Residual Deviance: 236.3     AIC: 242.3

title: Building models
text:
To use a model
Now we‚Äôve specified a model - how do we use it?

lr_spec <- 
  logistic_reg() %>% 
  set_engine("glm") %>% 
  set_mode("classification")

title: Building models
text:
To use a model
We can fit it to our data

lr_fit <- 
  lr_spec %>% 
  fit(Class ~ tau + VEGF, 
      data = alz)

lr_fit
#> parsnip model object
#> 
#> 
#> Call:  stats::glm(formula = Class ~ tau + VEGF, family = stats::binomial, 
#>     data = data)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#> (Intercept)          tau         VEGF  
#>      8.9747      -4.0095       0.9337  
#> 
#> Degrees of Freedom: 332 Total (i.e. Null);  330 Residual
#> Null Deviance:       390.6 
#> Residual Deviance: 236.3     AIC: 242.3

title: Building models
text:
To use a model
We can predict new data with the fitted model

alz_new <- 
  tibble(tau = c(5, 6, 7), 
         VEGF = c(15, 15, 15),
         Class = c("Control", "Control", "Impaired")) %>% 
  mutate(Class = factor(Class, levels = c("Impaired", "Control")))

lr_fit %>% 
  predict(new_data = alz_new)
#> # A tibble: 3 √ó 1
#>   .pred_class
#>   <fct>      
#> 1 Control    
#> 2 Impaired   
#> 3 Impaired

title: Building models
text:
To use a model  
We can predict new data with the fitted model and assess performance

alz_new <- 
  tibble(tau = c(5, 6, 7), 
         VEGF = c(15, 15, 15),
         Class = c("Control", "Control", "Impaired")) %>% 
  mutate(Class = factor(Class, levels = c("Impaired", "Control")))

lr_fit %>% 
  predict(new_data = alz_new) %>% 
  bind_cols(alz_new) %>% 
  accuracy(truth = Class, estimate = .pred_class)
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 3
#>   .metric  .estimator .estimate
#>   <chr>    <chr>          <dbl>
#> 1 accuracy binary         0.667


we can just do bind_cols() so easily because of the prediction format!

title: Building models
text:
The tidymodels prediction guarantee! 


The predictions will always be inside a tibble
The column names and types are unsurprising and predictable
The number of rows in new_data and the output are the same

title: Building models
text:
Your turn


Split the Alzheimer‚Äôs data and fit a decision tree.
What is the performance on the test set?

alz_split <- initial_split(alz, strata = Class, prop = .9)
alz_train <- training(alz_split)
alz_test <- testing(alz_split)




10:00

title: Building models
text: Cross-validation

title: Building models
text: Cross-validation

title: Building models
text:
Resampling 
What is in this?

set.seed(100)
alz_folds <- 
    vfold_cv(alz_train, v = 5, strata = Class)
alz_folds
#> #  5-fold cross-validation using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 5 √ó 2
#>   splits           id   
#>   <list>           <chr>
#> 1 <split [237/61]> Fold1
#> 2 <split [238/60]> Fold2
#> 3 <split [239/59]> Fold3
#> 4 <split [239/59]> Fold4
#> 5 <split [239/59]> Fold5



other types of resampling: boostrap, validation split
default is v = 10 but we don‚Äôt have sooo much data

title: Building models
section: We need a new way to fit
text:
We need a new way to fit

split1 <- alz_folds$splits[[1]]
split1_analysis <- analysis(split1)
split1_assessment <- assessment(split1)
tree_mod %>% 
  fit(Class ~ ., data = split1_analysis) %>% 
  predict(split1_assessment) %>% 
  bind_cols(split1_assessment) %>% 
  accuracy(Class, .pred_class)
# rinse and repeat
split2 <- ...

title: Building models
text:
Evaluating model performance

lr_spec %>% 
  fit_resamples(
    Class ~ tau + VEGF, 
    resamples = alz_folds
  )
#> # Resampling results
#> # 5-fold cross-validation using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 5 √ó 4
#>   splits           id    .metrics         .notes          
#>   <list>           <chr> <list>           <list>          
#> 1 <split [237/61]> Fold1 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#> 2 <split [238/60]> Fold2 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#> 3 <split [239/59]> Fold3 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#> 4 <split [239/59]> Fold4 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#> 5 <split [239/59]> Fold5 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>

title: Building better workflows
text:
Preprocessing options

Encode categorical predictors
Center and scale variables
Handle class imbalance
Impute missing data
Perform dimensionality reduction
A lot more!



recipes is an extensible framework
textrecipes for preprocessing text data

title: Building better workflows
text:
Penalized logistic regression

lr_pen_spec <- 
  logistic_reg(penalty = 0.1) %>% 
  set_engine("glmnet") %>% 
  set_mode("classification")



requires all numeric predictors
and all should to be centered and scaled

title: Building better workflows
section: What do you consider the estimation part?
text:
What do you consider the estimation part?


There are cases where this could go really wrong:

Poor estimation of performance (by treating the PCA parts as known)
Selection bias in feature selection
Information leakage

the more complex/powerful the preprocessing is, the more this is a problem!

title: Building better workflows
section: What do you consider the estimation part?
text:
What do you consider the estimation part?



applies to train vs test
also applies to all the cv folds!
tidymodels design principle is to provide tools that make good modelling practice easy: ‚Äúpit of success‚Äù

title: Tuning models
text:
hello world

placeholder: glmnet + tunable recipe
grids: space-filling manually
tune_grid = grid + fit_resamples
inspect results
decide on spec (model type, recipe, hyperparameter values)
finalize:
final performance assessment
use final model: predict or deploy

title: Tuning models
text:
Helpful resources

Overview of tidymodels with articles covering different use cases: https://tidymodels.org
Tidy Modeling with R book: https://www.tmwr.org
usemodels to create code snippets https://usemodels.tidymodels.org/

title: Building better workflows
text:
Introducing workflow()

alz_wfl <- workflow() %>% 
  add_model(lr_pen_spec) %>% 
  add_recipe(alz_rec)

title: Building better workflows
text:
Use a workflow

alz_wflow %>% 
  fit(alz_train) %>% 
  predict(alz_test)
#> # A tibble: 35 √ó 1
#>    .pred_class
#>    <fct>      
#>  1 Control    
#>  2 Control    
#>  3 Control    
#>  4 Control    
#>  5 Control    
#>  6 Control    
#>  7 Control    
#>  8 Control    
#>  9 Control    
#> 10 Control    
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 25 more rows

title: Building better workflows
text:
Use a workflow

alz_res <- alz_wflow %>% 
  fit_resamples(alz_folds) 
alz_res
#> # Resampling results
#> # 10-fold cross-validation using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 10 √ó 4
#>    splits           id     .metrics         .notes          
#>    <list>           <chr>  <list>           <list>          
#>  1 <split [267/31]> Fold01 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  2 <split [268/30]> Fold02 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  3 <split [268/30]> Fold03 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  4 <split [268/30]> Fold04 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  5 <split [268/30]> Fold05 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  6 <split [268/30]> Fold06 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  7 <split [268/30]> Fold07 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  8 <split [269/29]> Fold08 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  9 <split [269/29]> Fold09 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#> 10 <split [269/29]> Fold10 <tibble [2 √ó 4]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>

title: Building better workflows
text:
Your turn


Build a workflow with a nearest neighbor model and an appropriate recipe.
What are the performance estimates via 10-fold cross-validation?



10:00

title: Building better workflows
text:
Debugging a recipe
90% of the time, you will want to use a workflow to estimate and apply a recipe. To do it manually, prep and bake!

# prepping a recipe calculates the necessary estimates
alz_rec_prepped <- prep(alz_rec)

# baking a recipe applies those to a data set
bake(alz_rec_prepped, new_data = NULL)
#> # A tibble: 298 √ó 134
#>    ACE_CD143_Angiotensin_C‚Ä¶ ACTH_Adrenocort‚Ä¶    AXL Adiponectin Alpha_1_Antichy‚Ä¶
#>                       <dbl>            <dbl>  <dbl>       <dbl>            <dbl>
#>  1                    1.25            0.552   1.77      -0.227            1.03  
#>  2                    0.656          -0.261   0.833      0.137           -0.215 
#>  3                    1.98            2.08   -0.273      0.639            2.07  
#>  4                   -0.690          -1.31    0.489     -1.36            -1.42  
#>  5                   -1.13           -1.07   -1.44       0.489            0.447 
#>  6                   -0.397          -1.56   -0.273      0.0605          -1.67  
#>  7                    0.363          -0.645  -0.273     -0.848            0.0698
#>  8                    0.438          -0.0837  0.489     -1.29            -1.31  
#>  9                   -1.50           -1.31   -1.08      -1.58            -0.369 
#> 10                   -0.794          -0.854  -2.15       0.112            2.17  
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 288 more rows, and 129 more variables: Alpha_1_Antitrypsin <dbl>,
#> #   Alpha_1_Microglobulin <dbl>, Alpha_2_Macroglobulin <dbl>,
#> #   Angiopoietin_2_ANG_2 <dbl>, Angiotensinogen <dbl>,
#> #   Apolipoprotein_A_IV <dbl>, Apolipoprotein_A1 <dbl>,
#> #   Apolipoprotein_A2 <dbl>, Apolipoprotein_B <dbl>, Apolipoprotein_CI <dbl>,
#> #   Apolipoprotein_CIII <dbl>, Apolipoprotein_D <dbl>, Apolipoprotein_E <dbl>,
#> #   Apolipoprotein_H <dbl>, B_Lymphocyte_Chemoattractant_BL <dbl>, ‚Ä¶

title: Building better workflows
text:
Bundle components in a workflow()

alz_wflow <- workflow() %>% 
  add_model(lr_pen_spec) %>% 
  add_recipe(alz_rec)



can use other preprocessors: add_formula(), add_variables()
use a workflow like you‚Äôve use the model before

title: Building models
text:
Evaluating model performance

lr_spec %>% 
  fit_resamples(
    Class ~ tau + VEGF, 
    resamples = alz_folds
  ) %>% 
  collect_metrics()
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 6
#>   .metric  .estimator  mean     n std_err .config             
#>   <chr>    <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 accuracy binary     0.856     5  0.0186 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 roc_auc  binary     0.890     5  0.0178 Preprocessor1_Model1

title: Building models
text:
How did we do?

decision_tree() %>% 
  set_engine("rpart") %>% 
  set_mode("classification") %>% 
  fit_resamples(
    Class ~ tau + VEGF, 
    resamples = alz_folds
  ) %>% 
  collect_metrics()
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 6
#>   .metric  .estimator  mean     n std_err .config             
#>   <chr>    <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 accuracy binary     0.832     5  0.0229 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 roc_auc  binary     0.850     5  0.0325 Preprocessor1_Model1

title: Tuning models
text:
Tuning parameters
These are model or preprocessing parameters that are important but cannot be estimated directly from the data.

Some examples:



Tree depth in decision trees.
Number of neighbors in a K-nearest neighbor model.
Activation function (e.g.¬†sigmoidal, ReLu) in neural networks.
Number of PCA components to retain.



Covariance/correlation matrix structure in mixed models.
Data distribution in survival models.
Spline degrees of freedom.

title: Tuning models
text:
Optimizing tuning parameters
The main approach is to try different values and measure their performance.
The main two classes of optimization models are:

Grid search where a pre-defined set of candidate values are tested.
Iterative search methods suggest/estimate new values of candidate parameters to evaluate.

title: Tuning models
text:
Choosing tuning parameters    
Let‚Äôs take our previous recipe and add a few changes:

lr_pen_spec <- logistic_reg(penalty = tune(), mixture = tune()) %>% 
  set_engine("glmnet") %>% 
  set_mode("classification")
alz_rec <- 
  recipe(Class ~ ., data = alz_train) %>% 
  step_other(Genotype, threshold = tune("genotype_threshold")) %>% 
  step_novel(all_nominal_predictors()) %>% 
  step_dummy(all_nominal_predictors()) %>% 
  step_zv(all_predictors()) %>% 
  step_normalize(all_numeric())
alz_wflow <-
  workflow() %>%
  add_model(lr_pen_spec) %>%
  add_recipe(alz_rec)

title: Tuning models
text:
Grid search 

set.seed(9)
lr_pen_res <-
  alz_wflow %>%
  tune_grid(resamples = alz_folds, grid = grid)

lr_pen_res
#> # Tuning results
#> # 10-fold cross-validation using stratification 
#> # A tibble: 10 √ó 4
#>    splits           id     .metrics          .notes          
#>    <list>           <chr>  <list>            <list>          
#>  1 <split [267/31]> Fold01 <tibble [50 √ó 7]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  2 <split [268/30]> Fold02 <tibble [50 √ó 7]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  3 <split [268/30]> Fold03 <tibble [50 √ó 7]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  4 <split [268/30]> Fold04 <tibble [50 √ó 7]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  5 <split [268/30]> Fold05 <tibble [50 √ó 7]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  6 <split [268/30]> Fold06 <tibble [50 √ó 7]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  7 <split [268/30]> Fold07 <tibble [50 √ó 7]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  8 <split [269/29]> Fold08 <tibble [50 √ó 7]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#>  9 <split [269/29]> Fold09 <tibble [50 √ó 7]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>
#> 10 <split [269/29]> Fold10 <tibble [50 √ó 7]> <tibble [0 √ó 3]>


tune_grid() is pretty representative of their syntax (and is similar to fit_resamples())
grid can also be an integer for an automatic grid
to keep predictions: ctrl <- control_grid(save_pred = TRUE)

title: Tuning models
text:
Grid search
This is the most basic (but very effective) way for tuning models.
tidymodels has pre-defined information on tuning parameters, such as their type, range, transformations, etc.
A grid can be created manually or automatically.

title: Tuning models
text:
Manual grid - get parameters  

alz_wflow %>% 
  extract_parameter_set_dials()
#> Collection of 3 parameters for tuning
#> 
#>          identifier      type    object
#>             penalty   penalty nparam[+]
#>             mixture   mixture nparam[+]
#>  genotype_threshold threshold nparam[+]

title: Tuning models
text:
Manual grid - get parameters  



alz_wfl %>% 
  extract_parameter_set_dials()

This type of object can be updated (e.g.¬†to change the ranges, etc)


#> Collection of 3 parameters for tuning
#> 
#>  identifier     type    object
#>     penalty  penalty nparam[+]
#>     mixture  mixture nparam[+]
#>    num_comp num_comp nparam[+]

title: Tuning models
text:
Manual grid - create grid  
This is a type of space-filling design.
It tends to do much better than random grids and is (usually) more efficient than regular grids.

set.seed(2)
grid <- 
  alz_wflow %>% 
  extract_parameter_set_dials() %>% 
  grid_latin_hypercube(size = 25)

grid
#> # A tibble: 25 √ó 3
#>          penalty mixture genotype_threshold
#>            <dbl>   <dbl>              <dbl>
#>  1 0.124           0.309            0.00472
#>  2 0.0000000474    0.269            0.0272 
#>  3 0.0000000101    0.810            0.0205 
#>  4 0.0000140       0.527            0.0695 
#>  5 0.172           0.897            0.0160 
#>  6 0.0000329       0.701            0.0128 
#>  7 0.00000000610   0.590            0.0831 
#>  8 0.0141          0.102            0.0368 
#>  9 0.00513         0.405            0.0863 
#> 10 0.000667        0.145            0.00113
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 15 more rows



more space-filling: grid_max_entropy()
other: grid_regular(), grid_random()

title: Tuning models
text:
The results  


set.seed(2)
grid <- 
  alz_wflow %>% 
  extract_parameter_set_dials() %>% 
  grid_latin_hypercube(size = 25)

grid %>% 
  ggplot(aes(penalty, mixture)) +
  geom_point(cex = 4) +
  scale_x_log10()







Note that penalty was generated in log-10 units.

title: Tuning models
text:
Grid results 

autoplot(lr_pen_res)

title: Tuning models
text:
Returning results 

collect_metrics(lr_pen_res)
#> # A tibble: 50 √ó 9
#>         penalty mixture genotype_thresho‚Ä¶ .metric .estimator  mean     n std_err
#>           <dbl>   <dbl>             <dbl> <chr>   <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl>
#>  1 0.124          0.309           0.00472 accura‚Ä¶ binary     0.856    10 0.0109 
#>  2 0.124          0.309           0.00472 roc_auc binary     0.903    10 0.0207 
#>  3 0.0000000474   0.269           0.0272  accura‚Ä¶ binary     0.872    10 0.0141 
#>  4 0.0000000474   0.269           0.0272  roc_auc binary     0.902    10 0.0189 
#>  5 0.0000000101   0.810           0.0205  accura‚Ä¶ binary     0.883    10 0.0114 
#>  6 0.0000000101   0.810           0.0205  roc_auc binary     0.905    10 0.0177 
#>  7 0.0000140      0.527           0.0695  accura‚Ä¶ binary     0.872    10 0.0122 
#>  8 0.0000140      0.527           0.0695  roc_auc binary     0.900    10 0.0188 
#>  9 0.172          0.897           0.0160  accura‚Ä¶ binary     0.728    10 0.00247
#> 10 0.172          0.897           0.0160  roc_auc binary     0.832    10 0.0207 
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 40 more rows, and 1 more variable: .config <chr>

title: Tuning models
text:
Picking a parameter combination 

show_best(lr_pen_res, metric = "roc_auc")
#> # A tibble: 5 √ó 9
#>    penalty mixture genotype_threshold .metric .estimator  mean     n std_err
#>      <dbl>   <dbl>              <dbl> <chr>   <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl>
#> 1 3.11e- 3   0.869             0.0969 roc_auc binary     0.912    10  0.0185
#> 2 2.41e- 4   0.949             0.0460 roc_auc binary     0.909    10  0.0168
#> 3 5.13e- 3   0.405             0.0863 roc_auc binary     0.909    10  0.0193
#> 4 5.69e- 4   0.370             0.0426 roc_auc binary     0.906    10  0.0166
#> 5 5.41e-10   0.633             0.0357 roc_auc binary     0.906    10  0.0171
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 1 more variable: .config <chr>

select_best(lr_pen_res, metric = "roc_auc")
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 4
#>   penalty mixture genotype_threshold .config              
#>     <dbl>   <dbl>              <dbl> <chr>                
#> 1 0.00311   0.869             0.0969 Preprocessor14_Model1


You can create a tibble of your own or use one of the tune::select_*() functions:

title: Tuning models
text:
Your turn


Tune the nearest neighbor model.



10:00

text:
Returning results 

collect_metrics(lr_pen_res, summarize = FALSE)

title: Tuning models
text:
Deploy your model 
How do you use your new tree_fit model in production?

library(vetiver)
v <- vetiver_model(alz_final_fit, "alzheimers")
v
#> 
#> ‚îÄ‚îÄ alzheimers ‚îÄ <butchered_workflow> model for deployment 
#> A glmnet classification modeling workflow using 130 features

Learn more at https://vetiver.rstudio.com

title: Tuning models
text:
Deploy your model 
How do you use your new model alz_final_fit in production?

library(plumber)
pr() %>%
  vetiver_api(v)
#> # Plumber router with 2 endpoints, 4 filters, and 1 sub-router.
#> # Use `pr_run()` on this object to start the API.
#> ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ[queryString]
#> ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ[body]
#> ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ[cookieParser]
#> ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ[sharedSecret]
#> ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ/logo
#> ‚îÇ  ‚îÇ # Plumber static router serving from directory: /Users/hannah/Library/R/arm64/4.2/library/vetiver
#> ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ/ping (GET)
#> ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ/predict (POST)

Learn more at https://vetiver.rstudio.com

text:
Your turn


Run the vetiver chunk in your .qmd.
Check out the automated visual documentation.



05:00

title: Tuning models
text: Compare to GLM

title: Tuning models
section: Updating the workflow and final fit
text:
Updating the workflow and final fit  

best_auc <- select_best(lr_pen_res, metric = "roc_auc")
best_auc
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 4
#>      penalty mixture num_comp .config             
#>        <dbl>   <dbl>    <int> <chr>               
#> 1 0.00000281   0.223        3 Preprocessor3_Model2

alz_wfl <-
  alz_wfl %>% 
  finalize_workflow(best_auc)

test_res <- 
  alz_wfl %>% 
  last_fit(split = alz_split)
test_res
#> # Resampling results
#> # Manual resampling 
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 6
#>   splits           id               .metrics .notes   .predictions .workflow 
#>   <list>           <chr>            <list>   <list>   <list>       <list>    
#> 1 <split [298/35]> train/test split <tibble> <tibble> <tibble>     <workflow>

title: Tuning models
section: Compare test set and resampling results
text:
Compare test set and resampling results 

collect_metrics(test_res)
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 4
#>   .metric  .estimator .estimate .config             
#>   <chr>    <chr>          <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 accuracy binary         0.886 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 roc_auc  binary         0.824 Preprocessor1_Model1

# resampling results
show_best(lr_pen_res, metric = "roc_auc", n = 1)
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 9
#>   penalty mixture genotype_threshold .metric .estimator  mean     n std_err
#>     <dbl>   <dbl>              <dbl> <chr>   <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl>
#> 1 0.00311   0.869             0.0969 roc_auc binary     0.912    10  0.0185
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 1 more variable: .config <chr>

title: Tuning models
text:
Final fitted workflow
We can extract the final workflow, fit on the training set:

alz_final_fit <- test_res %>% 
  extract_workflow()

# use to predict
predict(alz_final_fit, alz_train[1:3,])
#> # A tibble: 3 √ó 1
#>   .pred_class
#>   <fct>      
#> 1 Control    
#> 2 Control    
#> 3 Control

title: Tuning models
text:
Updating the workflow

best_auc <- select_best(lr_pen_res, metric = "roc_auc")
best_auc
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 4
#>      penalty mixture num_comp .config             
#>        <dbl>   <dbl>    <int> <chr>               
#> 1 0.00000281   0.223        3 Preprocessor3_Model2

alz_wfl <- alz_wfl %>% 
  finalize_workflow(best_auc)

title: Tuning models
text:
The final fit  

test_res <- alz_wflow %>% 
  last_fit(split = alz_split)
test_res
#> # Resampling results
#> # Manual resampling 
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 6
#>   splits           id               .metrics .notes   .predictions .workflow 
#>   <list>           <chr>            <list>   <list>   <list>       <list>    
#> 1 <split [298/35]> train/test split <tibble> <tibble> <tibble>     <workflow>

title: tidymodels workshop
text:
Acknowledgements
These materials have been created by the tidymodels team along with Alison Hill.

title: Building better workflows
text:
A first recipe

alz_rec <- 
  recipe(Class ~ ., data = alz_train)

Based on the formula, the function assigns columns to roles of ‚Äúoutcome‚Äù or ‚Äúpredictor‚Äù

summary(alz_rec)
#> # A tibble: 131 √ó 4
#>    variable                        type    role      source  
#>    <chr>                           <chr>   <chr>     <chr>   
#>  1 ACE_CD143_Angiotensin_Converti  numeric predictor original
#>  2 ACTH_Adrenocorticotropic_Hormon numeric predictor original
#>  3 AXL                             numeric predictor original
#>  4 Adiponectin                     numeric predictor original
#>  5 Alpha_1_Antichymotrypsin        numeric predictor original
#>  6 Alpha_1_Antitrypsin             numeric predictor original
#>  7 Alpha_1_Microglobulin           numeric predictor original
#>  8 Alpha_2_Macroglobulin           numeric predictor original
#>  9 Angiopoietin_2_ANG_2            numeric predictor original
#> 10 Angiotensinogen                 numeric predictor original
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 121 more rows

title: Building better workflows
text:
A basic recipe

alz_rec <- 
  recipe(Class ~ ., data = alz_train) %>% 
  step_other(Genotype, threshold = .03)

title: Building better workflows
text:
A basic recipe

alz_rec <- 
  recipe(Class ~ ., data = alz_train) %>% 
  step_other(Genotype, threshold = .03) %>%
  step_dummy(all_nominal_predictors()) 



applied to all nominal predictors!
recipes selectors: by type or by role or both!

title: Building better workflows
text:
A basic recipe

alz_rec <- 
  recipe(Class ~ ., data = alz_train) %>% 
  step_other(Genotype, threshold = .03) %>%
  step_novel(all_nominal_predictors()) %>% 
  step_dummy(all_nominal_predictors()) 



Adds a catch-all level to a factor for any new values not encountered in model training, to avoid hiccups with new, unknown factor levels
before step_dummy()

title: Building better workflows
text:
A basic recipe

alz_rec <- 
  recipe(Class ~ ., data = alz_train) %>% 
  step_other(Genotype, threshold = .03) %>%
  step_novel(all_nominal_predictors()) %>% 
  step_dummy(all_nominal_predictors()) %>% 
  step_zv(all_predictors())

title: Building better workflows
text:
A basic recipe

alz_rec <- 
  recipe(Class ~ ., data = alz_train) %>% 
  step_other(Genotype, threshold = .03) %>%
  step_novel(all_nominal_predictors()) %>% 
  step_dummy(all_nominal_predictors()) %>% 
  step_zv(all_predictors()) %>% 
  step_normalize(all_numeric())



learn the mean and sd of each numeric column and save it to apply to any dataset to normalize
which brings us the question: what‚Äôs the estimation part?

title: Tuning models
text:
Finalizing the workflow

best_auc <- select_best(lr_pen_res, metric = "roc_auc")
best_auc
#> # A tibble: 1 √ó 4
#>   penalty mixture genotype_threshold .config              
#>     <dbl>   <dbl>              <dbl> <chr>                
#> 1 0.00311   0.869             0.0969 Preprocessor14_Model1

alz_wflow <- alz_wflow %>% 
  finalize_workflow(best_auc)

title: Tuning models
text:
Compare to KNN

show_best(lr_pen_res, metric = "roc_auc", n = 3)
#> # A tibble: 3 √ó 9
#>    penalty mixture genotype_threshold .metric .estimator  mean     n std_err
#>      <dbl>   <dbl>              <dbl> <chr>   <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl>
#> 1 0.00311    0.869             0.0969 roc_auc binary     0.912    10  0.0185
#> 2 0.000241   0.949             0.0460 roc_auc binary     0.909    10  0.0168
#> 3 0.00513    0.405             0.0863 roc_auc binary     0.909    10  0.0193
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 1 more variable: .config <chr>

show_best(knn_res, metric = "roc_auc", n = 3)
#> # A tibble: 3 √ó 9
#>   neighbors weight_func genotype_thresho‚Ä¶ .metric .estimator  mean     n std_err
#>       <int> <chr>                   <dbl> <chr>   <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl>
#> 1        15 rectangular            0.0205 roc_auc binary     0.837    10  0.0309
#> 2        13 inv                    0.0300 roc_auc binary     0.835    10  0.0262
#> 3        11 inv                    0.0120 roc_auc binary     0.831    10  0.0274
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 1 more variable: .config <chr>

title: Building better workflows
text:
Use a workflow

alz_res %>% 
  collect_metrics()
#> # A tibble: 2 √ó 6
#>   .metric  .estimator  mean     n std_err .config             
#>   <chr>    <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>               
#> 1 accuracy binary     0.762    10  0.0106 Preprocessor1_Model1
#> 2 roc_auc  binary     0.853    10  0.0153 Preprocessor1_Model1

title: Building better workflows
text:
Tidying a recipe

tidy(alz_rec)
#> # A tibble: 5 √ó 6
#>   number operation type      trained skip  id             
#>    <int> <chr>     <chr>     <lgl>   <lgl> <chr>          
#> 1      1 step      other     FALSE   FALSE other_50f3D    
#> 2      2 step      novel     FALSE   FALSE novel_AVARj    
#> 3      3 step      dummy     FALSE   FALSE dummy_jPsqy    
#> 4      4 step      zv        FALSE   FALSE zv_qylAU       
#> 5      5 step      normalize FALSE   FALSE normalize_u5u0m

title: Building better workflows
text:
Tidying a recipe

tidy(alz_rec_prepped, number = 5)
#> # A tibble: 266 √ó 4
#>    terms                           statistic    value id             
#>    <chr>                           <chr>        <dbl> <chr>          
#>  1 ACE_CD143_Angiotensin_Converti  mean         1.32  normalize_u5u0m
#>  2 ACTH_Adrenocorticotropic_Hormon mean        -1.54  normalize_u5u0m
#>  3 AXL                             mean         0.312 normalize_u5u0m
#>  4 Adiponectin                     mean        -5.21  normalize_u5u0m
#>  5 Alpha_1_Antichymotrypsin        mean         1.36  normalize_u5u0m
#>  6 Alpha_1_Antitrypsin             mean       -13.1   normalize_u5u0m
#>  7 Alpha_1_Microglobulin           mean        -2.93  normalize_u5u0m
#>  8 Alpha_2_Macroglobulin           mean      -159.    normalize_u5u0m
#>  9 Angiopoietin_2_ANG_2            mean         0.664 normalize_u5u0m
#> 10 Angiotensinogen                 mean         2.31  normalize_u5u0m
#> # ‚Ä¶ with 256 more rows


access the stats for a step (after estimation/prep)

title: Building models
text:
Prediction types

lr_fit %>%
  predict(new_data = alz_new, type = "prob")
#> # A tibble: 3 √ó 2
#>   .pred_Impaired .pred_Control
#>            <dbl>         <dbl>
#> 1         0.0505       0.949  
#> 2         0.746        0.254  
#> 3         0.994        0.00615

lr_fit %>%
  augment(new_data = alz_new)
#> # A tibble: 3 √ó 6
#>     tau  VEGF Class    .pred_class .pred_Impaired .pred_Control
#>   <dbl> <dbl> <fct>    <fct>                <dbl>         <dbl>
#> 1     5    15 Control  Control             0.0505       0.949  
#> 2     6    15 Control  Impaired            0.746        0.254  
#> 3     7    15 Impaired Impaired            0.994        0.00615
